1.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
1.content:
Here are the gound rules (no pun originally intended, even though I can see there IS one, as the poem that will get you started takes place in a coffee shoppe):

Rule #1:
Read the poem:

 Invalid Item 
This item number is not valid.
#489692 by Not Available.


Rule #2:
Don't change anything initially about the characters.

That is, for example, don't change the woman in the white suite with a cane into a t-shirt and blue jeans and have her in a wheelchair.

You need to keep the appearance, personality, etc. of the characters the way that they're described in the poem, if you're the first person to begin writing about each one.

If you're the next person to begin writing about the characters and want to change the description of them some, it must be done in a way that shows why (e.g. Using the woman as an example, you could have her returning home and changing into another outfit.

Rule #3:
Flesh them out.

Tell more about what these people are like without doing so in a way that seems as if you're just giving details. Work in, for instance, why the woman uses a cane or why the man's clothing is torn.

You might (probably, in a latter chapter) describe people, friends, and/or pets in their lives.

How old are they? Are they single, married, divorced, gay, straight?

Rule #4:
Once they've been described in a previous chapter, don't make drastic changes in them without a good reason.

That is: If one of them has been described as mentally-retarded in a previous chapter, don't make him/her into a college graduate in the next one.

However, you could take a mentally retarded character and have him/her to notice a gradual (or even a quick) increase in IQ after surgery, a special diet, a healing service, etc.

Rule #5:
Have a fun and creative time!

No further explanation needed.

Now, you're ready to begin!

Make your choice.

If, instead of choosing one of the four characters, you choose to be the person in the coffee shoppe who's observing them, the first person to write the personality of the coffee-drinking witness will be able to choose his/her gender and whether to tell the story in first-person or third-person.

For those who don't know, first-person is when you're telling the story as if your that person.

Here's a sample beginning:

After dropping Jason and Courtney off at school and Tiffany off at day-care, I decided to drop into Border's to see what was new in the way of books and indulge my tastebuds and spirit with some steaming cappuccino and tempting pastries. . .

Eventually, have this person looking out the window and wondering about these people. What will happen next? Will she simply go home and write about them? Will she actually meet one (or more) of them?

For third-person, you simply tell the story as a witness to it. I will change the above paragraph to third-person now.

After dropping Jason and Courtney off at school and Tiffany off at day-care, Sharon Vandiver decided to drop into Border's to see what was new in the way of books and indulge her tastebuds and spirit with some steaming cappuccino and tempting pastries. . .

I think I've covered all bases. Now, I'm just waiting to see where you will go with it.

Pick a person, and let the story begin. . .
1.title: Are You Ready To Begin?

choices: Continue to church, who cares what Lorticia MacDonald thinks
11.content:
I am on my way to church. South City Baptist Church. I am a senior deconess there. I have grown up in that church. I took on the bed babies nursery round about the time I had my first baby. I guess I was maybe 16 then. I watched those babies grow up in that church. Most of us live in the same neighborhood anyway. I have seen them get married. I have seen them have children, too many of them still children themselves. I have seen them go to jail. I have seen them leave the neighborhood, or stay. I have seen them get into drugs, taking and selling. I have seen them die.
Anyhow, I have a meeting now. I think I am going to be late. I move so much more slowly now. I really won't do for the senior deconess to be late, would it?
We all wear white. We are all deconesses at the church and we all wear white. White as snow. And we sit on the front row. I can't bear to walk all the way through the church in my suit with a big dirt streak on it. Lorticia MacDonald will never in a thousand years let me live it down. Still, I can't be late. So I am walking so much slower now, trying to decide.
11.title: Deconess' decision

111.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
choices: the teacher I had a crush on in high school
111.content:
I might be a little late, but I need to go home and change clothes. After all, it's a tradition for all of us deaconesses to wear white to church.

It's a good thing that I have a couple more white outfits that are clean and ready-to-wear.

As I near my house, I see somebody sitting on the front porch, and I can hardly believe my eyes.

It's none other than__________
111.title: Thw Guest

113.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
choices: join the young lady who's sitting by the window in Starbuck's
take a walk down along the river
113.content:
Suddenly the thought hit me that the dirt on my white dress was a sign that God was calling me to be somewhere else this morning besides traditional church. This happens at times--happens to other people, anyway, though this is the first time that this has happened to me.

I wonder if the others will be worried.

They'll probably be calling and coming to my house in droves to make sure I'm okay.

Oh dear! I hope they don't call the police or something and break down the door.

Oh well! I have no time to worry about that now--only about the present moment.

And, in this present moment, God has asked me to_____________.
113.title: An Unusual Sunday Morning

choices: He returns the next day with a card
He is caught, she reads of it and springs his bail
12.content: I am a second story man who tore his shirt on a rose bush while climbing over a fence after his latest daylight heist. Library card? You want me to rip off someone's library card for you? You'll have to wait; I'm busy getting someone a DVD player, but if you're here tomorrow I will see what I can do.
12.title: The Yegg

121.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
choices: One belonging to a certain celebrity
One belonging to a teen with Down Syndrome
121.content: I'm back with a couple of library cards. Which one do you want to be responsible for returning to the owner?
121.title: Return The Card Of Your Choice

13.content:
I always hated tweed. My grandmother had sent me the jacket a few months ago. It wasn’t exactly my style, but it looked like quality material. I couldn’t bear to give it to Sally-Anne without at least trying it first.
Big mistake. Stupid thing itches like crazy. I shifted my heavy bag on my shoulder and tried to scratch my side as I hurried down the street, past the onlookers in the coffee shop. I was counting the moments until I could finally unload the bag and the jacket for good.
It would have to wait until after the scrum.
After a long and controversial court battle, Dr. Steinburg’s harassment charges had finally been settled out of court. He was only going to be at the courthouse for an hour before his entourage would sweep him away from the media.
I humped the bag for some extra balance and, after a quick check for traffic, crossed the street on the red light.

The courthouse was just around the block. Not too much further to go. As I neared the second crosswalk, I caught sight of a peddler giving out some pamphlets. His white, thin t-shirt hung off his bony shoulders, which had goose-bumps from the cold. As I tried to veer around him, his blue eyes immediately focused on me. He began to walk in my direction.
Oh, no! Not me. I don’t have time.
But my conscience nagged me. He looks harmless. What harm would it do to accept the piece of paper?
13.title: To the Courthouse

132.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
choices: leave pamphlet in ladies room for someone else to find
132.content:
I read the pamphlet. It's very simple. It says:

The fact that you reached out and accepted this pamphlet from a person who might seem inferior--or even scary--to some shows that you're the kind of person we need in our organization. . .

The pamphlet gives a few details about the organization and lists a contact person to call.



I decide to__________
132.title: We Need Your  Type!

1321.content:
After the court trial and I am walking home, I remembered the pamphlet I had taken earlier. I stopped on the side walk and opened my bag to find it. I pulled it out and read over the text again. I thought; maybe I should give this person a call.
I reach my house and set down my bag and the tweed jacket on the kitchen table. With the pamphlet still in my hand, I walk over to my phone and start dialing the number. I wonder what this organization is about; I thought. The phone is picked up and answered by a man. "Uh, hello. I picked up one of your pamphelts today and I decided to call the number on the back to find out some information," I said. "Alright. Our organization is about helping homeless start a better life. And we are needing some more volunteer workers. Are you interested?" said the man.
1321.title: Calling

13211.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
13211.content:
I'm a practical sort of person--one who is given to think things over--but there was something within me saying that I was really needed, so I decide to volunteer.

The man tells me that there are a couple of things needing to be done right at the moment and wondered if I would want to volunteer to do either of them.

One is to be a tutor to a homeless child (several to pick from; both genders; and all grade-levels) who has gotten far behind his his/her studies.

Another is to help with the preparing and/or serving of food at an understaffed soup kitchen in a high-crime area.

Which should I choose?
13211.title: I Say "Yes!"-------And Then?

13212.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
13212.content:
Part of me says to jump right in with both feet, but there's that greater part of me that says to be cautious.

What I finally decide to do is to tell the man that I'd like to get back with him in about a month--or, possibly, less.

But I just really needed to further examine the pros and cons.

After I hang up, I take a sheet of notebook paper with the idea of dividing it into two sections:

Pros & Cons

I would list them and then go over all of them.

I began listing them--starting with these first two:

Pro--People are needed to do this, and I'm a capable person.

Con--But I have so many other things going on.

I continue adding to the list. . .
13212.title: Why Or Why Not?

choices: The pamphlet introduces a new way of thinking
The pamphlet is a ransom note
1322.content:
Appearances, appearances, appearances.
I'm not a bad person. I give to the United Way.
I watch Oprah. I took the pamphlet. People
were watching. At least I looked like I cared.
"Thank you, ma'am," he said, breath smelling
like a hallatosis buffet. Last thing I wanted
was an argument, his reasoning why I needed
to read it for a chance at salvation or
inspiration or enlightenment or another
noseful of the fish and chips he'd smeared
down his throat for breakfast.

At the courthouse, I'd made a B-line for the
restroom, stomach damning my love of street
vendor ice cream and intolerance of lactose.
Usually, my habit of misreading time
schedules raised my stress levels; today,
though, after finding out I was an hour too
early, it was paying off when I needed it most.

Sitting on the toilet, eyes wandering across
the door, brain musing through auto-pilot, I
thought of using the pamphlet as toilet paper.
Not that the type of paper it was printed on
was ideal for the task or anything; it's that I
could wallpaper my living room with the ones
I've gotten in the past year alone and I would
have at least enjoyed the opportunity to use
one for something more that a donation to the
local garbage hill. Donate this. Renounce
that. Embrace the other thing and give, give,
give.

My sweater itched.

My guts were on fire.

The pamphlet was an annoying bulge in my
pocket. Out of frustration, I crumpled it up and
threw it on the floor.

But there was something on that pamphlet
that I recognized...
1322.title: Bathroom Enlightenment

choices: The person in the shop smiles and waves
The person in the shop looks embarrassed and turns away
14.content:
I stopped my ferrari to let a woman in a tweed coat cross the road-even though it said "Dont Walk".
As I started the car again I glanced over at my wife and wondered why I had married her.
Maybe I was too drunk the whole of the high school year I dated her...and still drunk when I proposed...
It had been two years of unhappy marriage.
We were just too different...
I liked books, small parties with close rowdy friends of mine, beer and kids.
She liked large parties, gaudy jewelry and hated kids and beer and all my friends.
I wondered yet again why I had married her.
I was snapped out of my thoughts by my wife.
"Check out that weird person staring at us in the coffee shoppe Nayle!" she poked me in the arm.
I turned my head to look.
14.title: A Ferrari and an Unhappy Marriage

142.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
142.content:
The person in the coffee shoppe doesn't seem weird at all--though, perhaps, a little shy.

However, I find her shyness endearing--and it's mu guess that she's studying people but got embarrassed when my wife and I noticed.

How do I know this?

Because I, too, love to study people--though I get a little self-conscious when caught doing so.

I wonder about this woman--as well as about the one in the tweed jacket.

Both of them seem like women I'd love to spend time with.

No, I'm not talking about an affair or anything like that, because I don't believe in cheating on my wife, no matter how unhappy our marriage is.

All I know is that I'm lonely for "real" conversation.

Maybe, if Sheena and I really work on our marriage, it might actually get better. I guess I want to give it a fair chance before giving up and filing for divorce.

But, in the meantime, it would be nice to not feel lonely.

Maybe, this woman frequents the coffee shoppe. Who knows? Maybe the woman in tweed also stops in there on occasion. I wonder where she's going to.

I see her heading into this tall office building.

I would like to get to know both ladies. Which one should I try to meet first.

"Nayle!" my wife screams at me. "Watch where you're going! You passed the street you were supposed to turn on, and, now, we will have to go all the way to the end of this street before we're able to find a decent route back to it! Don't you have any brains in there!?!"

"I didn't know that how many brains I had mattered as long as I brought home my regular paycheck for you to spend," I mumbled.

"WHAT?"

"Oh nothing! Never mind!" I knew right then how starved I was for someone to talk to. I decided to go to the coffee shoppe around this time tomorrow just in case the people-watching lady were in there. I really wanted to talk to her--really NEEDED to talk to her. . .

The next day, I went to the coffee shoppe.

For some reason, the thought of going there had also made me sexually-aroused, but I concealed my arousal as bast as I could.

After all, I didn't want to cheat. I was only lonely for someone to talk to.

I think that, perhaps, sexual arousal and respect go hand-in-hand.

I had long lost respect for my wife, so it was difficult to even stsy focused enough to get through "doing it" with her--and that seemed to be okay with her.

Even though she made barbs about my being a sexual flop to me, it didn't seem to me as if she really cared that much one way or the other.

Would this change if we were really to work on our marriage? Get counseling, perhaps?

Anyway, I was having a little problem here. I honestly DID want what I shared with this woman to be a platonic sort of thing.

No matter how miserable my marriage was, I certainly wasn't going to cheat. In the first place, it just wasn't right--period!

In the second place, even without having yet gotten to talk to this woman, I could tell that she was too sweet to ever be put through being "the other woman."

Right at the moment, though, I really needed some relief.

It had been so long since I'd felt this kind of sexual tension--in fact, I don't know if I ever HAD.

Sheena had been the first and only woman I'd ever slept with--even though she had been with at least two other guys before me--and it had happened for the first time when I'd been drunk.

After that, I had convinced myself that, since I'd slept with her, she must be the one meant to be my wife.

That seemed to be fine by her at the time, so we became engaged and married right after high school graduation.

I drove to an old cemetery about five miles out of town and found a place to park in the oldest section of it.

It didn't take me much time at all to get some initial relief--even though it took two more very earth-shaking sessions before I was able to finally get my urges under control.

As I relieved myself, I was thinking about making love to this woman--should I be thinking those thioughts? And why was I? I didn't even know her. She could be even more nasty than Sheena!

NO WAY! I could tell just by looking at her that she wasn't at all like my wife.

I knew that we would be having some very pleasant converations together--and I also knew that, likely, I would probably need to drive to the cemetery first before meeting her.

Was this love at first sight?

SHOULD it be with my being married and all?

Should I simply begin to give up on ever getting this charade of a marriage to work without even trying to go to counseling?

Most importantly, what was it about this woman that elicited such strong emotions within me--not just sexual ones but, also, ones of longing to get to know her.

Feelings of missing her before even meeting her.

Now that my sexual urges had been tamed for the time being, I drove to Borders.
142.title: Making Plans For Drinking Coffee

choices: Continue looking for the other woman
1421.content:
Bodies sat evenly spaced from one another, apparently trying not to get too close to others. As his eyes roved from one person to the next, resting for mere seconds on each before deciding they were not she, he wondered if there was anyone here who, like him, desired to know anyone else in this place. A few friendly souls sat with other people, speaking animatedly in quiet voices, but most sat quietly with a newspaper or book, eyes down, not wanting to meet the roving eyes of a stranger.

Next to the glass windows he noticed a woman. She was a small woman; even her oversized blue parka could not hide the fact. It did not compliment her figure, nor her pale skintone, he noted as his eyes took in the pale color of her neck, and her light hands tinged pink with cold. His eyes roved lower, taking in the erect way she sat, and the dark jeans which clung tightly to her thin, crossed legs. Her hair matched her skin; it was that light ashy-gray-brown color that escapes colorful description mostly because it escapes most people's attention. However, unlike most women, she'd not had her hair colored and it had a certain shine that lured his eye like the distinct sparkle of a diamond as she tilted her head to read the opposite page of a thick book she held against the table with her forearm. It was not the curious woman he'd felt oddly attracted to yesterday, he knew, but he wondered if he should approach her anyway.
1421.title: The woman by the window

choices: Pick up what she had dropped and give it back to her
Get the thing she had dropped but keep it
Knock on the window and shout "Hey lady!"
15.content: I sat staring out the window, downing the last dregs of my double latte. I couldn't understand why I was still tired. My day at school had been fairly taxing, but I had got a good night's sleep the night before. But I could feel my eyes drooping regardless. As I stared out the window, I saw a woman hurrying by in a tweed jacket. She had a look of concern on her face, and as she rushed by I noticed the bag on her shoulder was open and something had fallen out of it. What would I do?
15.title: Tired

151.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
choices: asked me if I had a moment to talk
151.content:
I made my way outside quickly, picked up the item, and gave it back to the lady.

The lady looked at what I'd given her, and________
151.title: Returning The Item

152.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
choices: go out an confront them myself
ask the cute guy  at the next table if he'd do it
152.content:
Before I could leave my seat to retrieve the dropped object, a couple of boys who looked to be about eleven or twelve years old picked it up.

They were looking at it.

I couldn't see what it was, but I noticed that both of them had ornery looks on their faces and were snickering.

Whatever it was, they had no right to keep it and make light of it, so I decided they needed to be stopped, and so I___________.
152.title: Snicker-Snicker!  Heh-Heh!

153.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
choices: nothing but an empty lot  full of tall weeds
153.content:
I went outside to pick up what she'd dropped, intending to give it to her, but, because I was so listless, everything happened in slow-motion--meaning that, by the time I'd retrieved it, the woman was long-gone.

Not to worry, though, because there was an address and phone number in the front of what seemed to be a personal journal.

I would call her when I returned home and let her know that I had her journal.

I've always enjoyed reading online journals belonging to other people, and I was tempted to read this one--but I told myself that it wasn't an online journal, so it wasn't something meant to be read by an outsider.

No, I would simply take it home, call the lady, and make arrangements to return it to her.

When I got home, I dialed the number in the journal, but all I got was a recording saying that the number was no longer in service.

I try dialing it again--more carefully this time around--and get the same results.

So, I decide to go to the address given inside the book as soon as I took a nap.

It was almost sunset when I left to drive towards the address.

When I got to that address, I found__________
153.title: Returning A Journal

info.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
info.brief_description: You probably don't know these people--but just pretend that you do!
info.description:
Imagine that you're drinking cappuccino in a bookstore coffee shoppe and looking out on the passing parade of people, and four different people catch your eye. . .

Actually, you don't have to do all of that, because the first part of this exercise has been done for you, as you'll find out when you read Chapter One.

But there will still be plenty of chances to become creative after that.

Dare you enter in!?!. . .
